f6PrSWLYI7sdps4nYyzPOQ.text: Good food but really stingy portions for the price- 3+ dollars for a side dish and got maybe 3 tablespoons of food?  Disappointing.

j9nQOeE-j3P8XrKT4Db50Q.text: Great idea, thank you!  - healthy but fast lunches, wow, what a concept! - locally sourced eggs and other farm products, you care! - housemade everything, no frozen crap - great, fast breakfast in the morning with tons of healthy but tasty options - pretty good cup of coffee as well  - Only complaint, don't be afraid to let the chalk board menu signs get messy - use them, we wanna know what today's "soup of the day" is.   Good job!

PEQ6PZRxkhTPm759E_aL3w.text: I have become a Bluebird addict for both breakfast and lunch.  Try the Pastrami-cured Salmon with cucumbers on an everything bagel for breakfast.  The egg sandwiches are to die for as well.  At lunch, their poached tuna nicoise salad with mustard vinaigrette is the perfect mix of healthy/delicious.  Soups vary daily, and I have tried about 10 different ones without disappointment.  They had Borscht one day which was phenomenal.  I keep hoping for its return!

2_OCPqVQNV1snjJXtAJT2g.text: Just wanted to add that the customer service is so far above average here.  It so nice to be treated like a human being who matters by the people who you give your money to, which is something that's seriously lacking in many other eateries downtown.  The addition of the cordons and stools puts the finishing touches on this already amazing place.  And don't miss the baked goods.  Liz better hang on to that pastry chef; I see great things in her future!

l6gvHYUbSEmU_glItEAI1w.text: Great atmosphere and concept. I ordered the chicken salad sandwich. The homemade croissant was good but the chicken salad was a little dissapointing. Too much cashew and it had a different taste to it, maybe they used a mayo substitute? It was alright overall, I would give this restaurant a shot again, just not the chicken salad

LZscca_AMxcsj4_jT8Te3g.text: I love this place. I trust their food and it's such a pleasant place to have breakfast or lunch.  There are always vegan and gluten-free options but some great meat options too.  The oatmeal is delicious (get all of the toppings!) and the grits have bacon and 2 fried dippy eggs on top.  The Tuna Nicoise is a delicious salad and other reviewers aren't kidding: the mustard dressing is fantastic.

LokD8AX1ictvnGsJLrF2vA.text: Fun place to do a light breakfast. I would highly recommend this place to anyone who doesn't want a grease belly all day. The hash I had was inventive although just a squeak dry. Not a lot of room to eat inside so on a good day eat outside on market square.

pJ4xZ0pFPKXb8aA0m9-c9w.text: Excellent quality fresh foods.  Not cheap, but good food rarely is.

-S77XKAllpbKpAsuvthA3w.text: For a small business, they sure don't want more business! I called today (12/31/14) to see what the soups of the day were and the owner answered and said "uh, yeah, we just closed. We were only open until 12." I realize that it is New Year's Eve, but you are a business in a downtown area and people work on New Year's Eve day. This has happened a few times before with this location (their Stanwix location, I was told, has been closed ALL week), so I'm left wondering, are you a small business trying to stay in business?? Just curious because I would be happy to take the $10+ I would have spent (not to mention the 3+ co-workers who were all coming with me to go out to lunch) and spend it at another restaurant in Market Square or Downtown Pittsburgh. Your establishment isn't THAT phenomenal where I need to go back.

0kvpOD_2pJukE7p3ubzWjQ.text: The food is wholesome and delicious.  The staff are good-looking and well-mannered, but they are painfully slow.

aLPJUXyLkg_acwUxbzPpjQ.text: After 3 sub-par experiences I felt obligated to review.  1) Ordered  sweet potato hash. The staff admitted the potatoes had oxidized a bit and didn't  look appealling. They tasted Ok, but were extremely greasy.  2) Went in for coffee. There were at least 5 people in front of me waiting to order. After a few minutes of waiting without one of those people ordering, I walked out. 3) Ordered the parfait. Expected yogurt.  If it was yogurt, it didn't taste like it. It was the consistency of stiff whipped cream and didn't have much flavor. Impossible to stir. I didn't  finish it.

dR587AbI23W1liu4yMYc5A.text: What a gem of downtown!  This places serves the best sides in town. I regularly go to bluebird to get a side of quinoa or panzanella to accompany my sandwich. Also the chocolate pistachio cookie is rich and delicious!  Don't forget dessert when you go here!

0ZVdTZWET-EOl5DXU8pPjw.text: Came in for breakfast and will come back! Got the pastrami salmon... Delicious! Nice staff.. Winner winner

T6UpoUyR5-u2qrXBvX3aCw.text: I was in Pittsburgh for a few days for business.  I really wanted to try breakfast, but didn't have time to squeeze it in prior to scheduled meetings for the day.   I did however visit for lunch on a Wednesday afternoon.  At 12:15, the place was pretty full, with people in line wating to order and well as customers waiting for their orders.   There was a pretty decent list of sandwiches, salads and soups.  I opted for the Rotisserie Chicken salad sandwich which had apples, cashews and curry seasoning on a homemade croissant.   I also opted for a side salad of grains and vegetables.  The sandwich ($8.50), was a little bit pricey but, it was pretty fresh and tasty.  The chicken was a bit salty, but all in all the combination was spot on.   There were multiple side salads displayed and available.  I opted for the Farro, strawberries, veggies and figs in a honey balsamic dressing, or at least that's what the sign read.   When I arrived back to my office, I actually had a salad that was completely different with asparagus (I'm allergic) and tofu, savory, not sweet.  I removed the  asparagus and enjoyed the remaining salad.   This place was a bit chaotic, but I would return....the food was good.

y9rK5wBTl6KfkLzH22R8lg.text: I so love this place when I was living downtown Pittsburgh. Its my #1 choice for my breakfast and lunch. Frittata Sandwich and Chicken salad sandwich are just some of my favorites. I have brought some of my friends to eat with me here and they love it. The place is very nice and neat. The people who work here  are so friendly and awesome! Some of them even knows my name which really feels good as a customer. I can't help myself but to keep getting back here. Very recommended. Still going to visit this place when I get back to Pittsburgh.

Rspm4_7uu1FFVlfsgCLZOg.text: Great fried egg, cheese, tomato and sausage for $6 plus a great macchiato and not overly sweet cinnamon roll. You've gotta go. Seems like a place that would be in SF or NYC. And that's a good thing.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried egg with cheese and sausage + macchiato

c4e2fyo2W67iusFYGUH8bw.text: Tuna Nicoise salad was really delicious - fresh, great house-made sun-dried tomatoes, and a killer mustard vinaigrette. Didn't get to try a vegan chocolate chip cookie, but I will definitely try a pastry or cookie the next time! Very friendly and helpful staff.

Qn0PXk4SxRWyt725URCAzA.text: Bluebird is indeed, as good as it gets for lunchtime fare in downtown Pittsburgh. I'm sure it is for breakfast as well; I just haven't made it in that early yet! I adore this restaurant - both locations on Forbes and on Stanwix. Everything I have ever tried has been wonderful! Everything is fresh; lots of local sourcing, imaginative menu items and salads every single day. The sweets are dangerously awesome. I won't go on, but if you're looking for some fabulous, healthy and creative soups, salads and sandwiches, plus a hot entree option daily, Bluebird is your place.

qHxDHDvPCFxggUAniS79AA.text: I had a mocha and the bluebird granola, greek yogurt, fruit  and honey parfait. They both exceeded my expectations. The staff was friendly and helpful. I would come here again. The only thing that would have made it a better experience for me would be a more comfortable environment, like comfy chairs to sink into. That, however, would likely interfere with busy lunchtime traffic.

401YwmZoDXsky6atm61kew.text: Interesting lunch, in a good way. I had some kind of brown rice and zucchini salad, which was very flavorful and the soup   Was also tasty. I will go there again. I liked the vibe. Good lunch option in Pittsburgh.

a3oZAtwj0myMIi7Ofh9t6A.text: We thought we were walking into a sit-down cafe/restaurant so it kind of threw off our experience. Overall, the food was decent and I was happy to find that most of it is organic and made in house. Not a mind blowing experience.

iduim1OLhVx-bPAb0nJJkA.text: (Stanwix) Have you ever been to a place where the staff act as if its your pleasure to simply walk in??? Well welcome to bluebird! Beyond the nice/nasty lukewarm staff the food was soaked in grease....disgusting.  Neither of the staff at the front counter could be bothered with waiting on me as they were holding a conversation much more important than working.  After I finally was given the privilege to order they both went back to the kitchen to see if what I wanted right off of the menu could be made!!?   There was no one else in the restaurant and now I see why.   I get the whole hipster restaurant gimmick but the half a** service I can do with out.

HRxkzYQdqd9IvLOQD4pARg.text: Customer service was extremely poor. I specifically asked if the potato soup contained meat and I was confidently told no by the cashier. I started eating within the restaurant and came across what seemed like chicken, so I asked the cashier if she could identify what was in my soup since there was no meat included in the ingredients. She then said that she didn't know, but that she was sure the chef said there was no meat in the soup. I walked away, but wasn't satisfied with this answer, so I went up again and asked if she could ask someone else what it was that was in my soup I was eating. The cashier then turned to another employee and said "here you deal with this, I don't know" and put her hands in the air. The second employee looked at my spoon and said that she didn't know what it was and repeated that it wasn't meat. -__- She then calls the chef to see what was in my soup. The chef observes and says that it looks like chicken and that someone must've used the wrong ladle - causing there to be chicken in the potato soup....Someone who I assumed to be the manager apologized and gave me a refund. The two women were rude, uninformed, and unapologetic. I didn't appreciate their attitude towards me for asking about the ingredients in the food they were serving. This was my first time trying bluebird kitchen and I won't be back.

DGt2kKuHU3FwN9sYOQfgTg.text: Very nice addition to the Market Square area. I went for lunch and enjoyed the simplicity of the menu (soups, salads, sandwiches), but the complexity and thought that went into the individual items.  I had the smoked turkey sandwich, and unlike the majority of smoked turkey sandwiches, it really tasted smoked. Very delightful. I didn't have any desserts, but one of the people I went with had a fudge brownie and said it was delightful. All the baked goods looked succulent.   The staff was extremely friendly, overall a nice experience.

k0RQg7QojqupmeY3rITbpg.text: We ate here for breakfast one day we had to be downtown. My daughter visiting from Lancaster mentioned it. It actually is reminiscent of some places we eat breakfast in Lancaster when we visit there. It was on my list of places to visit, but I never seem to have that list with me when we're trying to decide where to eat. I had the Frittata on a ciabatta roll. That phrase just rolls off the tongue The roll was fresh and soft, not too chewy. The filling was very good and didn't fall out as sometimes happens in such sandwiches. Same for the Local Fried Eggs that my daughter also ordered on the ciabatta roll. She and I shared the Blue Bird Granola, also very good, but I would have liked a bit more honey or fruit to sweeten a little more. My husband had the Biscuits and Gravy which he orders just about everywhere he finds it on the menu. He said it was good which is just about as good as his praise gets. My daughter tasted it, and said it was delicious. We chose to sit at the counter to eat, although we saw many people getting take-out orders. We didn't notice when we entered how close Market Square was or we might have gone there to sit and eat. The seating isn't the best for comfort if you decide to eat there. We also found the paper container for biscuits and gravy a little disconcerting although understandable for take out and the environment. I would recommend the Bluebird Kitchen for breakfast and will return to try other things on the menu.

hghuyV1bjyBkdIKX4OfaGA.text: Amazing breakfast and lunch spot in downtown Pittsburgh, right off of Market Square.  Their menu has seasonal items that change each month, but the main sandwiches/salads stay the same.  They always have a variety of cold salads and cookies/pastries on the counter.  Limited counter seating, so it's not the best spot for a large group.  The order line does get backed up, but the staff does a great job of keeping it moving.  My favorites are the turkey sandwich and the cuban.

IAP0pDlp2-i4HdHP1nIHSQ.text: The food is typically great.  The service today was terrible.  I waited over 15 minutes for a simple off the menu sandwich while the shop was essentially empty.  After multiple inquiries, I finally left without lunch as no time remained.  The staff were doing anything but waiting on customers.  This was a favorite lunch spot but I won't be back .

_AH4RjAWcktdJu5K1k1syg.text: Food is tasty and fresh. I love the oatmeal for breakfast and their bakery items are super delish and unique (bacon glazed cinnamon bun anyone?). Lunch is super pricey, though--$12 for a tiny salad. I'd go somewhere else for lunch but I liked breakfast so much I ate here 4 days in a row!

ftt6JAbGmNCVCqJMmu1oOQ.text: Excellent lunch selections! Cute little bistro with great salads, sandwiches, and different sides every time. No way you can walk in there without getting a sweet treat. The thanksgiving lunch special was the best surprise! You will not be disappointed. Smaller place so seating is limited.

uZ4gCu6w5M_kpa9ndNMXUg.text: I'm in love.  Hands down one of the best lunch places in downtown Pittsburgh.  I love their sandwiches, and rotating hot meal menus or special of the day.  Their desserts are uber tasty and unique and the staff is friendly and so helpful, kind, and they know how to dress!  They are super busy during lunch with a line out the door.  So I suggest you go there early (rather than late - they tend to sell out of the specials).   Definitely stop in if you are in the market square area of downtown Pittsburgh.

g1gKfNlwKKAvnJyF2SgFwQ.text: I'm only reviewing their espresso and vibe and service. LOVE.   btw, I go during the quiet time of the day. I have had some of their food but I can't afford to do that much. The sides I have had have been great. The monthly vegetarian sandwich not so much, but I've only tried that once or twice.

H6HfZYzTTzIS-Q_B4Ynssw.text: In town for a conference all week: ate the "2 local eggs on ciabatta" 5 days in a row very very happily.  Several days I added the sausage to the sandwich: the sausage was hearty and flavorful: tasted like real meat, not grease.  The breakfast sandwich also had a few slices of tomato and lettuce which were great.  Also had an iced Americano a couple days and their iced coffee a few times.  This was quite passable, notably better than the chain around the corner. Happy to find this quality breakfast in the skyscraper part of town.

dbB0TyyRsY8vVpdd_oiDpQ.text: We stopped into the Bluebird Kitchen for lunch on a Thursday afternoon.  First thing I noticed was the cleanliness and the minimalistic decor.  The counter is a walkthrough line and it moves relatively quickly.  The food options are all listed on the board on the back wall.  I chose the cuban sandwich, the hubs chose the roast beef sandwich and we shared an order of the fresh veggie pasta salad.  I also ordered a green citrus iced tea and the hubs got a bottle of water.  The tea was so good.  I wish I'd gotten a second one to go.  The cuban sandwich was not at all a typical cuban sandwich.  We are long time residents of South Florida and it's difficult to get a real cuban sandwich up here.  Nothing tastes right.  I think it's because folks can't get the Spanish ham or the real cuban bread up here.  The flavor was good, but just didn't hit the spot for a cuban sandwich.  The roast beef was very good.  It had juicy roast beef, roasted red pepper and arugula.  Both sandwiches were served on a fresh baked ciabatta roll.  The veggie pasta salad was delicious! There were tons of veggies (squash, zucchini, tomatoes, and asparagus) as well as white beans and was dressed with what tasted like a homemade Italian type dressing.  The seating inside is limited to 3 counter type areas with stools.  We managed to procure a couple of seats by the window in the front.  Both of us enjoyed our meal and it was great option for a healthy meal on a warm day.  The service was stellar and the ladies behind the counter were super nice and helpful.  I can tell they really take pride in their business.

uD7rWbeYryFutPbqA4-YOg.text: Favorite go to breakfast and lunch spot: whatever you want it's so good!  Breakfast smoothie is so good - it is a monthly special but delicious! The breakfast sandwich is good on both ciabatta (home made and soft - very good!!) and the pretzel roll is always delicious

WTDZiUJI3ld7ObjqQH0sMg.text: It was lunchtime on Thursday and all the other popular restaurants were packed so I needed a quick and healthy meal to keep me going. Bluebird kitchen was clean and affordable with so many interesting sandwiches, pastries, and salads. I ordered the chicken salad on a croissant and my girlfriend and I shared the pecan pie chocolate bar. The sandwich was a bit small but the dessert was plenty to keep us satisfied. It would be nice if the sandwich came with a side item but I'm happy they gave us water for free to drink with the meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chocolate pecan pie bar
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken salad on croissant

2pmartB7nBlQoqWAYk7zlw.text: Semi- regular patron, I only go there for the biscuits and gravy. My problem is with consistency. Good biscuits but the gravy is hit or miss. I don't think they use a recipe everyday.  Presentation is sometimes in a big box with lots of gravy or in a little box with barely any gravy. (Always 2 biscuits) depending on who is working the amount of gravy varies as well the quality.   I have had the best and the worst biscuits and gravy here but I am always paying $7.49 for a dish comprised primarily of flour and butter. Which isn't worth it most of the time... but when it's good it's damn good.  This has been my experience the past couple years,  good enough (sometimes) to go back but the price and inconsistency are the reason for 2 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

gAkBhNH8mzSYY5DezgJpjw.text: Pretty good sandwiches and pastries. Also had an iced coffee that was great.   Just be aware there's a window between 10:30am and 11 where they switch from breakfast to lunch and you can't order some things during that time.

p9q0wY1MdvBALUBeWPvPDg.text: Finally! This review is LONG overdue - during the last year or so working downtown has given me multiple chances to eat at the beloved Bluebird Kitchen. I've come here for made-to-order breakfasts and lunches alike, and nothing has disappointed.   Their enormous breakfast sandwiches and fresh fruit smoothies leave me feeling full and satisfied, moreso than other places with similar breakfast options; the potato, sausage, egg and goat cheese laden frittata sandwich is a definite favorite. And their lunches are also a wonderful and tasty option should I forget to bring something to work that day. Their roast beef and Cuban sandwiches have been my favorites so far.  If you're the type who likes seasonal items, Bluebird offers monthly smoothies and sandwiches as an addition to the standard menu. I tried their special vegetarian sandwich from last summer (with fried green tomato, grapefruit & cabbage coleslaw) - I admittedly remember that sandwich being on the bitter side, more so than I expected as someone who likes both green tomatoes and grapefruit. It wasn't bad though, and it was certainly a unique flavor profile compared to what I typically find for a quicker downtown lunchtime option.  It's definitely safe to say that this place has knocked it out of the park and made my taste buds very happy time and time again. And that's just considering their main meals - the amazing desserts elevate your meal options to an entirely different level. They're good. They're really good. You should go buy one of them in addition to a sandwich. And oh: this review is based on my limited perusing of the menu - I have yet to try their biscuits, granola, quiche, bread pudding, and salads.  I know getting to Bluebird before they close can be a chore if you're not nearby, but they're worth it. Stop in and enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

vLX-P3O6yNziMKZM4ZKnFQ.text: Clean and easy to navigate once you walk in.  Order then sit and everything in Togo box so makes easy to eat there or take to go.  Food was really good and good price. The staff was awesome and very helpful with questions and accommodations

ap3am0t6H4vAA4UzutWw6A.text: Bluebird is the type of place Pittsburgh wants for their next generation. They're trying to be trendier and give a more hipster feel to the new places. Obviously the old diners and blue collar joints aren't leaving, but the people in Pittsburgh are making a real concentrated effort to add things to their city that more resembles something stolen from Brooklyn. I can dig that.  Bluebird is tucked into Forbes right around the corner from Market Square. It's a fresh space with a counter in the front of the store and a couple of tables to the side. Giving a nod to the name, the color tone is a calming blue that relaxes you. It's so warm and inviting you almost forget there's almost no seating for people!  My dad and I both ordered lattes, and I was a bit famished so I decided to order the grits. He went for a blueberry muffin as he has much more self control than me. We received our lattes and pastry almost immediately, and were able to snag two seats at the counter right before my bacon cheddar grits became available.  The lattes weren't my favorite, but they were acceptable enough that if my dad asked to come back I would be okay with it. He enjoyed his muffin and I dug right into the grits. They were perfectly cooked, and included a large mound of cheese and a wonderfully executed runny egg. There was also a lot more than I was expecting; I had trouble finishing it all! My only qualm was that it was served in a cardboard to-go box. I understand that may be the cool thing to do, but it was a little difficult to make sure a huge mess didn't end up on the counter. I can't imagine the mess you'd have to sop up if it were taken to-go.  I would visit here again. I think I may have chosen the wrong drink, but I loved the atmosphere and the food was delicious.

lwefbACzoTKz2vrdQxcR2w.text: Nice little breakfast spot. Not a ton of seating, but we got seats against the wall. My group got the salmon bagel, breakfast sandwich, sweet potato corned beef hash, and Southern grits as well as some coffees. Everything was pretty good. I wish on the egg sandwich they would ask how you want the eggs done. Normally I like runny eggs, but they don't work well in sandwich form. I also wanted to try the pretzel roll but they were out. The ordering system is also a little confusing. You order food at the back then order drinks and check out at the front and you have to repeat all the food you ordered. Overall, a good spot for a quick weekday lunch.

yYaYGH1YlPfsQwDabSOotg.text: I work 2 blocks away, so this has been a consistent breakfast (and lunch) stop for me for years. I figured it's about time to give them some Yelp love. Their smoothies are my main attraction most mornings, though their sandwiches are great grab and goes to take back to your desk. The only downside is there is often a long line, but it's worth the wait!

ZwevZYjCpSR7vwGdpQZ2hg.text: Stopped in about 2 months ago for a cup of soup and piece of bread. The soup was bland and unmemorable; I can't even remember what it was. The "bread" was a piece of bagel, which seem strange.   Apparently I forgot about my previous experience and stopped by today for soup. I ordered chicken tortilla soup. When I got back to my office I opened my bag and got a strong whiff of chicken noodle. I opened the cup and it looked like chicken noodle. Out of the 3 soup options I didn't think chicken noodle was even an option so I called the shop and asked what was in their tortilla soup. I was told it had chicken, carrots, onions, broth, and little pieces of tortilla. No tomatoes, beans, corn, or anything you would normally find in tortilla soup.  This is when I remembered my previous experience. I will not be returning.

6OkSTaN8dcopQIBGt49Akg.text: Disappointing. Walked out because no one wanted to actually take an order for a leafy salad. Girls behind the counter were more interested in letting me know I had zero clue where or how to order a salad. Understood it's downtown at noon, but given that there were only two people in line I don't see a good reason for the condescending and bothered behavior. Skip this place and get a great customized salad at Hello Bistro. Leafy salad at Bluebird is pre-made in a cooler, which makes the difficulty in deciphering the convoluted ordering process even more baffling.

eJw9UXrnhcalH-TthKcilg.text: Great breakfast options for vegetarians. I enjoyed a fried egg sandwich and small oatmeal. Coffee is good as well. I'll return the next time I'm in Pittsburgh.

i8-Y6dlWrrJzRI7sFgqIqg.text: The breakfast menu is limited and it's more to grab something to go; you won't get bacon and eggs on a plate.  The coffee is good, but the barista said she needed to the manager to make a cortado...?  The lunch sandwiches are great, especially the chicken salad. I love that is comes on a croissant which is worth eating just as a croissant!

c3R7LMf_hBf3Y1PAEdB_mg.text: Nothing really special for lunch. It's better than fast food but the prices seem high for what you get. I ordered a salad with chicken, blue cheese, pears and nuts. It was mostly lettuce and it was pre-made. My husband had a chicken salad sandwich and there was very little chicken. I would just stick to baked goods here. I would view it as a bakery and not really a restaurant.

roalT5zlr0f6BQsfen_OHA.text: Bluebird Kitchen is a decent place to stop and eat at if you are downtown and want to grab something quick and healthy. Everything is pre-made and al la carte. The only downside is their selection is pretty small and since everything is pre-made you can't omit or add anything. Their house made potato chips are some of the best chips I've had.  They do have an awesome selection of desserts.  If you're not already downtown I wouldn't go out of my way to stop here. Parking downtown is too much of a pain.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cauliflower soup
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Best housemade potato chips
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Roast beef sandwich

AZQkVaC4USSQLGL79rxPNw.text: Food was pretty good. The staff seems disinterested. Took a long time to get food. There are better places to eat in Pittsburgh.

1aeYdiIN9sNzVhZ1ikCEcw.text: The food is wonderful here. Baked goods and breakfast foods alike. However, if you're in a rush, don't recommend going here. I waited 45 minutes for an egg and cheese bagel and was terribly late to class one day. The sandwich was AMAZINGLY tasty, but I didn't have time for that. The cookies are wonderful as well!!

ZVgw1uiAyU1rz4LI1NbD-w.text: Months ago I wrote a raving review about Bluebird Kitchen; however after this morning's 25 minute wait for a toasted bagel and cream cheese I can't say that I'd go back there. I stood by and watched order after order come out from the kitchen wondering where my order was. I realized afterwards that the staff at the counter are responsible for simple toasted orders. Those staff members prioritized customers' orders that came in after my own, which allowed my wait time to continue to build. Needless to say I wasn't impressed by their customer service whatsoever. Don't bother checking this place out, it's not worth the time.

I9fRYyfnin7PO9mZYiuuIA.text: My family and I were visiting Pittsburgh and happened upon this restaurant. It was really good. It's not a conventional style like a lot of restaurants where you order at your table. At this restaurant, you order at the counter and the waiter/waitress brings it to your table.   They have breakfast and lunch. We were there for breakfast. They also have lots of good looking and tasting pastries. I had the grits with cheese, chopped bacon, and egg on it. It was one of the best grits I've ever tasted. My dad ordered the quiche of the day which had butternut squash and fennel in it. He liked it. My mom ordered the fruit parfait. She liked the granola in it.   For dessert, I had their scone of the day which was cinnamon raisin. It was good. It was very dense. It was not too sweet though which I liked. My mom and dad ordered the bread pudding of the day which was maple blueberry. They liked it.  If you're ever in Pittsburgh, you have to try this place!

oCuxoPrp3WFcd1eqaMqzqw.text: Yet another welcome addition to the the Market Square dining scene!  Bluebird Kitchen does things a little differently than some of the other new places in the Square...it offers breakfast for one.  And the breakfast offerings sound quite nice...but I can't imagine ever having time to swoop down the street in the morning from Grant Street.  That means you lucky folks in the lower area of downtown won't have to fight off we intruders from the the upper area!  I'm envious.  Lunch, however, is another thing.  I'll be back frequently for the fresh salads and other items on the menu!  Lured by the prospect of "crispy" porkbelly, I ordered the May's salad.  Besides the aforesaid porkbelly, it consisted of arugula and endive, slivers and flecks of smooth gouda, roasted thyme onions and slivered pear with a mustard vinaigrette I could have eaten with a spoon it was that good!  The porkbelly - and I'm a big porkbelly fan, mind you - left a lot to be desired.  Not crispy at all, it was a generous portion of what appeared to be raw thick-sliced bacon.  I know it wasn't raw....it just looked that way.  It was chewy and had strings of inedible rind.  That went on the side and remained uneaten.  Ugh.  But the salad itself was wonderful.  Next time I'll get ANYTHING other than the porkbelly.  The service is friendly, efficient and QUICK!  You're in and out - even with a line in front of you - faster than you imagined possible.  Don't expect to eat in comfortably...take your prizes outside to the tables in the Square and enjoy some al fresco dining...or take it back to the office.  Side note:  a colleague of mine ordered the porkbelly sandwich and found the same problem with the porkbelly.  Some work is needed on a better preparation of that particular product.

GG6EXgmTw-3644J6_6iWTQ.text: I stopped by Bluebird Kitchen the other day to grab some breakfast. I thought the place looked fantastic and modern. I can tell they must get some decent lunch business because most of the space is reserved for ordering and waiting for your food. There are two long shelf tables where you can sit, a little uncomfortably, and eat your food within. It is nice to be able to eat and look out at the passing downtown crowds though. I got the egg sandwich. It was decent, but I will never understand why one would want lettuce and tomato on a breakfast sandwich. After taking those off, I enjoyed the sandwich. The egg was cooked to perfection and was runny, just as I like it. Fortunately my girlfriend had my back with a handful of napkins! The coffee was good, and hot. No complaints there.  The wait time for my food was a little longer than I had expected, especially since there was not a line to order. I guess that is the trade off for freshly cooked food. I think this place would be exponentially better if they had table service, but the space may not be there for this. Overall, this is a great addition to Market Square and I look forward to trying lunch.

fuyTomLlqFwtJkzsx-3HqQ.text: Stayed in Pittsburgh for 3 days. Had breakfast here all 3 mornings. Gorgeous oatmeal. Beautiful granola with fruit and great European style coffees. Highly recommend this place. You won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

6XguuoIppuIs1z8Z9tLePw.text: I got the pastrami cured salmon bagel twice this week before work. The first time is was delicious. The second time the bagel was too stale to eat. Why would they serve that? Throw it in the toaster?   I think I'm done with this place.

NXaTmuh1B0VGpudcKDzB9Q.text: Seriously, how am I supposed to get lunch anywhere else now?  I just started working downtown and after finding The Bluebird Kitchen I don't think anywhere else will compare.    First time I went (yesterday) I ordered the Croque Monsieur, and I'm not exaggerating when I say it was an out of body experience.  The brioche bread was amazing, then add the ham and gruyere, and you have an unreal sandwich.    Today when I went back I ordered the Cuban, and again was thrilled.  I topped it off with a chocolate chip cookie which was delicious as well.    The only draw back is their lack of seating, but I'll happily take my lunch anywhere I can if it tastes like this.    If you are downtown for lunch, don't go anywhere else, I don't think I'll be able to...ever.

vIyZ-8NevwsEs4QUxf3jvQ.text: Updated 9/2016 - love that I can always count on a dairy free/ gluten free option at lunch! it's so great to have a restaurant with great food that is thinking about this! I've been going pretty much every day when I visit Pittsburgh - breakfast (sweet potato hash is great) and lunch!

zMa7JabwanekBySOKr4Jlw.text: Missed out on breakfast so we got lunch instead. I got the July vegetarian and y boyfriend got a chicken salad. Both meals were incredible. My meal was a sandwich and it was life changing. Bye.

ftnbC7bcPBG-CoGKuYbgnA.text: So I have been here twice and had two pretty different experiences.  The first time, L and I went for lunch to grab something and bring it back to work to eat in the office since we knew that there was no seating in the place and it was farmer's market day in Market Square.  We both had the veggie sandwich on rosemary and sea salt foccaccia. We also decided to splurge and split the oatmeal sandwich cookie.  Can I just say wow!  Both the sandwich proper and the sandwich cookie were delectable!  The veggies were perfectly cooked - zucchini, red peppers and onions.  They were covered with a lovely melting of cheese.  The sandwich cookie was to die for - much like the one from your childhood, but adult sized and adult taste.  Today, my friend S and I went and were just kind of lukewarm.  I ordered the home made turkey sandwich and he got the chicken salad croissant.  His croissant was much too hard and the salad was more of chicken and mayo.  He opened it to show me and I was surprised there was nothing else in there.  My turkey sandwich had an amazing jam on it - hard to describe, but excellent and the cheese was definitely above par, but the turkey was odd.  I know that it is homemade, but it was too gelatinous for turkey from a place like that.  And the bread was a bit stale which I found hard to believe seeing as how we were the first customers in there.    All in all, I had a fantastic experience and a so-so experience.  I will likely be back in the future with hopes that today was an off day.

kNFzCOlxj7zAjGtjKBdGww.text: The Cuban might be the best sandwich in the city.. seriously.. porky, salty, juicy, pickle-ee, flavor-dripping-down-your-face, kinda good... and I'm sure the Local Fried Egg sandwich is the best breakfast sandwich in the city... rich, and yokey.  Look, if you want fries on your sandwich, or a crappy buffalo chicken wrap, or processed cold cuts, then this place just isn't for you.  This is real food people. Food that starts out as quality ingredients, that are transformed into a wonderful, delicious products.  When you're baking your own bread and pastries, roasting and braising your own meat... that's cooking. That's what we're supposed to be eating.  I can't say enough about people who treat food  with the proper respect it deserves.  It's absolutely refreshing in this world of chained, crappy, processed, mediocrity.

tREDfr0Lpf5g5Xu3IElGKA.text: review for location in First Niagra building:  sandwiches are good but over-priced so i would not recommend them.  However, the salads are very good, I am a health conscious eater and ordered a tuna salad.  It came without the mayo and contained half of an avocado, very well made and healthy salad if you are looking for a healthy light lunch.

01pVius9i1lZLDpDAadkVQ.text: It's a great little place for lunch. They don't have much seating, so if you get lucky, take advantage of it. You're near Market Square, so takeout is also a great option. My favorite is the chicken salad. It's not your normal recipe, so I suggest trying it. They also have a great macaron selection, which makes for a great desert back to the office. They sell Slingshot Coffee, a great coldbrew. Not many places have it in the area.

N0POnoLHvDNQ1zEqSSSLPA.text: At first glance, I thought "kinda pricey" but I tried it out anyway. I didn't expect much from the Croque Monsieur sandwich (basically a ham sandwich), but the gooey sauce or cheese was delicious with plenty of ham and crunchy bread which altogether made it more than just a simple ham sandwich. Delicious. I still think the prices are a bit high though.

LH88YN4qjd1KvA-4e9qdPg.text: It makes me sad to no longer be working in downtown Pittsburgh, because I will no longer be able to stop in at Bluebird for the Tuna Nicoise salad. This is, hands-down, my favorite salad that I don't make myself, and beats out anything I've received in a full-service restaurant. Also worth trying their Cuban and Chicken Salad sandwiches. If I had only one complaint, the prices are on the high side for the portions, but the quality and location (being downtown) make up for it.

j3U97ZlYWyMJ0z2k86e6xA.text: I went to the Stanwix location and I will say that while the layout was certainly aesthetically pleasing, I was not immediately impressed with my options. However, after trying a few different options, I was very satisfied. I tried their vegetarian option with crushed chickpeas. The  sandwich could have used a sauce or something, it was a little bland. The bread was phenomenal, I don't know if they make it or not but it really made the sandwich. I had their tomato and fennel soup which was unique and so good. I tried a brown rice and asparagus side dish that was also absolutely great. My other side was roasted carrots, farrow or barley and a yoghurt sauce which was surprisingly tasty. Overall, great food and I didn't feel guilty about eating it. Will be back.

x-FmYKm1PWQFyPUV2t9JtA.text: So glad we stumbled upon this place while visiting Pittsburgh. Our sandwiches were great (House Roast Beef and Croque Monsieur) and the potato salad was delicious, but what I really want to write about is the apple pie that was being served while we were there... I cannot remember the complete list of ingredients or exactly what the pie was called, but I can say that was absolutely the BEST apple pie I have ever had in my life. Every bite was PERFECT! Next time we are in town we will certainly visit the Bluebird Kitchen again. I can only hope and pray that the apple pie is being served again, but if it's not I'm sure there will be another dessert just as delicious!

BdThebYWUgmSHWSCfY2y1Q.text: The BF and I were looking for a simple brunch/early lunch after flying in from Chicago. The four star rating I saw made me pick Bluebird Kitchen but we're leaving disappointed. The price of the food does not match the quality. I ordered the chicken salad sandwich, which was handed to me from a cooler in the back, and my boyfriend ordered the August salad, which he was told to pick from the cooler in front. I understand being prepared for the lunch rush, but why even call yourself a kitchen if you're simply handing out prepackaged food like 7-11? My chicken salad was entirely too salty, and my boyfriend's salad had bitter lettuce. Disappointing. And the customer service is likewise disappointing, as other Yelpers have mentioned. No one walks you through the menu, or explains why they serve some foods prepackaged or some foods hot.  TL;DR not coming back and not recommending it.

hYmUhR807492gXO04LHCug.text: The boy and I also frequent this place for lunch. We've been going here since it opened and I must say, I'm impressed. I really loved their May Veggie Sandwich (not their July, but the boy really did). I love how they change their menu every month. What a great idea! And from what I understand they use local produce! Plus two for them!

GmXeMlIo385s-YoUv3YjTA.text: Really impressed with everything here. The chicken & brown rice soup was delicious. The sandwiches were amazing. The coffee was great too. And the staff was really helpful and kind.

_7yHx7FkO7wV7izhJi3LXg.text: I had a breakfast sandwich and orange juice. Both were very good. A little on the expensive side but the food was worth it.

sPlBPbDWsD1DXR-1LC8NfQ.text: nice place to kill some time. only seating available is two bar type counters that run along the walls. about twelve stools total. have ordered something different each time visiting and it's always delicious. iced coffee is good. GREAT place to people watch. customer service could be better and it's always kind of dirty- crumbs on the countertops and the floor is always littered with little bits of trash or food crumbs. overall they deserve a B-

AM5ib-a1xkPE8ASAxM8-Dw.text: Not bad! I had the tuna salad and it was okay.   The staff was very nice, pastries looked delicious. I am glad I know for the next time I am in town! They have day old pastries that are discounted and looked just as yummy!!

Rr9R6mHDcqGFrdYxytsoPg.text: They have good, strong but not burnt iced coffee and very nice vegan baked goods! I've been lucky enough to try their vegan chocolate chip cookie, fluffed nutter cookie, and the walnut banana bread but the original choc chip cookie is my favorite! One of the best vegan cookies I've had.   Have stopped by a couple times during both lunch and a bit later in the afternoon and they weren't too packed, although seating is limited. I would consider this a more take-to-go type of lunch spot rather than a sit down coffee shop.

edOVVP_HmwfiI2SmvN79fw.text: No way what a sham of a place. It's one of those hipster aesthetic "cafes" that are overpriced and super slow. The menu is very narrow - and if you have dietary restrictions you're probably down to 1 or 2 sandwich options. They only have 2 hot sandwiches too. It was 10$ for one sandwich and it doesn't come with any sides or anything.   Particularly displeased by the staff. There were 5 people behind the counter who seemed to be very young - probably in their teens or twenties. I'm in my twenties myself, but they were so unprofessional. The gentleman who served me didn't know anything about the menu. It seemed like they didn't have a dress code and I found that they were on their phones or meandering and sitting at the tables for most of the time I was there.   There were two women were great and seemed to be calling he shots. But truly, that's all you needed. Why do you need so many bodies behind the counter? Especially if they're doing nothing and just chatting? My sandwich also took forever to get to me. For some reason they decided that they needed to distribute the 3 people before me and after me all at the same time. Instead of as they were done. So strange.   Also a car alarm went off outside for a couple minutes and it seemed like the world was ending for the staff. "Omg does someone not care at all about their car" and "wow this is SO annoying" was all I heard. They were more whiny and annoying than the car themselves!   Hard pass on this place. So many more cheaper, and better places in market square. Not going to come back until they have a management intervention.

y2iev6qS44JR7x1nbkedBQ.text: My sandwich was so mediocre - actually borderline bad - I'm pretty disappointed. 3 stars because the staff was very nice and service was fast. But my sandwich came out so quickly that I think it actually lends to it being so meh (very little spread, barely covered the bread, sloppy, etc.) The description made it sound like it'd have lots of flavor, but it was extremely bland and very dry. I might come back to try some of the pastries, but as another reviewer said, "sandwiches are nothing to write home about." And pricy - $10.17 before tip, no side.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. House Roast Turkey Sandwich

GK0_kQ_6Zv3U2geEp-9XMA.text: Came in for a few sandwiches for lunch, which were on the small side and weren't too exciting, especially for the price. While we didn't get any of the baked goods, they certainly looked good and probably are this spot's forte. Would probably check out again for that, but the sandwiches were nothing to write home about.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

z1hZ1fpWiEWH3voZRe9Umw.text: This was my second visit and each time I feel like I've found a hidden gem. If you're downtown for breakfast, lunch or looking for a coffee break, Bluebird is a must visit.   They recently hired a new pastry chef and you can tell. I arrived around 8 and the case was filled with everything you can imagine - muffins, scones, cupcakes, quiche. I started my day with the Chocolate Chip Espresso Scone and an Early Grey tea... both we're perfect.   Then by lunch time the pastry case filled with an entirely new assortment + a variety of cold salads. They have a hot menu for both breakfast and lunch as well as pre-made salad options if you're on the run. The wait for food orders didn't seem to take long.   They have plenty of stool seating around the perimeter of the room. If you're lucky on a sunny day you can sit right in front of the large windows facing into market square.   I have to note they also sell pastries from the previous day at 1/2 off! Prices are super reasonable, but I love a place who doesn't let food go to waste.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pastry case at breakfast time
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Early grey tea with espresso chocolate chip scone

VwVxWGnmVShw1d4eut_T2Q.text: I'm not often downtown during the weekday but now and then I get that opportunity. Bluebird kitchen is a small take out cafe where everything is made from scratch. They serve breakfast and lunch and close at 3 weekdays only.  Breakfast is served until 10:30 with lunch service starting at 11. If you prefer to eat in then there is a long bar overlooking the outside window and another off to the side. Portion sizes are very generous and you do get more bang for your buck here. Everything is made in house here.  Since the day of my visit was frigid cold I wanted to order one of their three soups they make daily. The potato leek soup looked inviting and it comes in two sizes. It also comes with a fresh cooked roll. I was going to order a sandwich to go with it but after learning they were big I decided to stick with a side of Brussel Sprouts, squash, red pepper and white bean medley.   Some of their food is marked vegan and gluten free options are also available. The entire menu is on separate chalkboards along with a listing for coffees, teas and Sam Pelligrino. They also have a grab and go fridge just below the check out area for things such as salads, cold bevvies and other things that need refrigerated.  The staff is very helpful. You order on one side and they will bag up your items in cardboard when you are ready to check out. After paying I sat down and believe me that soup was so soothing and good that I felt a lot warmer already.  You can also tell it was homemade by the way it tasted. The Brussel sprout medley was also very good but very filling!!! I was so tempted to get a dessert especially when I was eyeing those double decker macaroons but I was already too stuffed. You have a great selection from consisting of anything from parfaits, cookies, breakfast pastries, and double decked goodies.  Bluebird kitchen has a 2nd location at 11 Stanwix St  not too far from here by Keybank. They also do catering. Information is available online or in the shop.  This is a great spot for the working class and you can get a descent meal for a good price. Located on Forbes Ave across from Revel + Roost and Millie's ice cream public transportation is available.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Part of the lunch menu and desserts. V also can mean vegan as well as vegetarian
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Brussels sprouts medley with yellow squash, white beans and red peppers
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bread for soup-definitely fresh!

u2f1nGLVzQIN39y_vtronA.text: One of my favorite lunch spots downtown- delicious salads, sides, sandwiches, and soups. I almost always get the Tuna Nicoise salad- it's huge and has a delicious mustardy dressing paired with it. My only complaint is all the salads are premade- I'm sure they are made that day but I like to be able to customize so would prefer them being made in front of me. There is always a line so get there early! They also serve coffee and baked goods- which always look amazing!

_pTjx1AZdVJM23l331hSKw.text: Bluebird is your quintessential downtown lunch spot. Bluebird packs a counter full of delicious and homemade cookies and pastries all of which are delicious. The cookie sandwiches are a great sweet midday treat, but best to split if you don't want a sleepy afternoon.   In addition to the baked goods, Bluebird offers a number of hot and cold daily sandwiches and specials. The sandwiches all come on homemade bread and are a substantial amount of food. They also serve two soups and salads which rotate on a daily basis. Bluebird has a great location right off marker square, and while there is seating, it's limited so most people take out. It can also be busy during peak lunch time if you're ordering a hit sandwich while crunches on time.

nWprR_k_kxjrh2kOwPkYag.text: Yummy homemade sweet potato hash with an egg.  Lotsa food for a great price.  People working there super nice and friendly.  Had an ice coffee and a humongous scone to go (snack for later while I'm headed to all day conference around the corner.   A nice morning to enjoy my breakfast outside in market square.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sweet potato hash

-eU4rF3O1DZfolBuYiyLBQ.text: This is just about the cutest little restaurant around. The menu is tightly edited, with a great selection of baked goods and hot dishes. It is a little tough to read through the menu before it's your time to order and it's helpful just to ask what types of baked good are available - you can see things but there aren't signs to tell you what's what.  My blackberry muffin was incredible tender, studded with big whole blackberries that somehow didn't make the muffin gloppy. I was shocked at the $2.50 price tag - super affordable for this type of freshly baked good. I only regret I had one morning free to eat here!   Order at the counter, then find a place to sit. They'll call you when your food is ready to grab.

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Blackberry muffin
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

_P_Ve6FFvBf66iB3wVnoWQ.text: Bluebird Kitchen is my go to spot when I want to grab a quick breakfast downtown before work.   Their breakfast sandwiches are great but my go to is their sweet potato-corned beef hash. It's the perfect balance of sweet and savory. However, the last time I ordered this dish it was very greasy. I normally order just a regular coffee and it's pretty good; they serve Counter Culture Coffee.  The staff is normally wonderful! They're friendly and very helpful.   I normally get my order to go. This cafe is definitely on the small size. There's no tables, just one long counter against one wall and another against the window both with bar stools. It can get crowded if you during the morning rush.   This a great place if you're looking for a quality breakfast downtown on the go.

mJUk1RbW6OcvhIGmOKhBRw.text: Love this great little lunch spot. The homemade bread used on every sandwich I've ordered is some of the best bread I've ever had! Their sandwiches, sides, and desserts are unique and delicious. The display of pastries and desserts is oh so tempting. I've only had their cold and hot sandwiches, but I'm sure I'll eventually be back to try their salads and soups as well. The staff is always friendly and the atmosphere/decor simple and pleasant with counter and bar stool seating around the perimeter and super high ceilings make the space work well for casual dining in or picking up to go!

ixK1m_4vWkxYn8tYnQbA4Q.text: This is a cute cafe, with  great  service  and friendly  staff. I've only had the cured salmon bagel. Ask for it toasted, it's  incredible. It  takes  a little  long to  get to you but it's worth  the  wait. The seasoning  on  the everything  bagel is the  best  I've  ever  had, and the  salon  is  delicious, a unique take on just  normal  lox. Super good, would  highly  recommend.

l42P-Ozx74hxp-aVCC9lag.text: Visiting Pittsburgh for the week, and I was looking for a breakfast and coffee spot, which led me to bluebird kitchen.  Their breakfast ends at 10:30, and the transition between 1030 and roughly 11:00 AM. The only items available are what's available at the front, and nothing is sent to the back. I ordered a spinach and kale quiche, that took about seven or eight minutes to warm up. When I received it, part of it was still cold probably because of the size of the quiche which was more than generous. I felt like it lacked certain degree of flavor, but the eggs were extremely soft and fluffy. The crust was also crispy. I do not think it was anything to write home about. Coffee was strong as I had hoped. I also got a blueberry doughnut cake, which had a dense consistency, and I enjoyed the real strawberries. It was a perfect combination with the coffee.

vES5MFbS7j_W0MoEMqBxGg.text: The vegan chocolate chip cookie was THE best.  Turkey sandwich was meh.  Seriously, go here for the cookie.  I'm not a vegan, and it was a top 5 best chocolate chip cookie ever.

2dbsR5Za8qvoaENhpyYUvA.text: Really friendly service and quick! I had the small portion of the sweet potato hash and WOW! So delicious and so filling and what a great take on corned beef hash. We took our food out to the Market Square and enjoyed watching the morning bustle of downtown Pittsburgh.   What's more is that I needed to contact Bluebird afterward about getting an itemized receipt so my work could reimburse me, and they were so kind and fast with my request! They emailed me the receipt within 24 hours. Great food great folks.

V6-bWd2zNsOZBNynpDSwkw.text: Dropped in here while randomly walking through Pittsburgh! Employees were kind and friendly. The vegetarian selections were limited, but I decided on the quiche of the day, which happened to be made of broccoli, sweet potato and gruyere. They took the time to warm it up for me (it did take approx 8 minutes for anyone in a rush), and I took it to go. I didn't get a chance to eat it until later in the day, but it was by far the greatest quiche I've ever eaten in my life. The egg had a pudding like texture, the crust was hearty and not soggy at all, and the flavors were on point. Every time I eat any type of egg based food I usually have to eat it with hot sauce or ketchup, but this quiche needed absolutely nothing. I would absolutely come back to get it again if I'm ever back in town.  On another note, there is no table seating - just stools and two long counters facing either the outside window or the side wall.

3jn19b8YZKJf34IQNqWZeQ.text: Soups not good. Got broccoli cheddar and it's just green liquid with no texture. When I think of broccoli cheddar soup I envision creamy cheddar soup with broccoli floating through it. Second time I got soup there and both times, took a spoonful or two and threw it away. Plus it's over $5 a cup. Just not good.

VLwBMieJKC4p7dMMNYn8WA.text: Stopped in here on a whim with my dad for a quick bite to eat before he left town. The menu is great for breakfast and lunch! The oatmeal look super great, as did all the pastries (which I'm gonna have to go back for later!) I stuck with their baby romaine salad - truthfully, I thought it would be rather dull but I just needed something quick and healthy. It ended up being absolutely amazing and so filling! Feta, cucumber, almonds, dates, lemon zest and a champagne vinaigrette. SO good!  My dad had a spinach chicken soup which he loved, as well as the house roasted chicken salad. Both of us left there happy - this is probably from a combination of the great coffee they have as well as great food choices!  Not to mention - a very friendly staff. Will definitely be back here!

xKeIjaOKaIvdst6nomtlfg.text: We just missed breakfast and I was a little bummed because I wanted to try the pastrami salmon. But I am so happy we decided to stay for lunch. I had the cuban and my girlfriend had the roast beef sandwich. Both were excellent (ask for a side of horseradish sauce for the roast beef). Coffee was great and was served in a huge mug. We has a hard time deciding on a side because they all looked so good. The sweet potato and black bean salad was excellent. I couldn't believe how reasonably priced everything was for being made in-house and organic. Great healthy spot that won't hurt your wallet.   That being said, the highlight for me was the Honey Tuilles. Oh my god was that good. I need to see if I can get them shipped down south because I might be addicted!

565oX-8Kn6sIv-CaVkTSyQ.text: One of my favorite places for breakfast/lunch in Pittsburgh.  Sure, Pittsburgh is the land of crepes and waffles and giant, starchy, breakfast meals, but, for the same price, you can get a sandwich and a fruit/veg salad at Bluebird Kitchen!  The breakfast egg sandwich is delicious, as are the Cuban and croque monsieur lunch sandwiches.  But my favorite eats are the salads - beet with lime and cilantro, cauliflower with chickpeas and curry, spinach with oranges.  All so good!  I'm totally on board with the restaurant's idea to source fresh, local, foods and craft the menu items as appropriate.  Oh and the baked goods are a treat!  I've had a couple of the cookie sandwiches and macarons and they did not disappoint.  A yummy, creative, thoughtful alternative to the traditional Pittsburgh breakfast joint!

nBp0YO5Hp5ya-GnzXvToFQ.text: Very good food, but poor service, wasn't greeted coming in, employees seemed like they were each zoned out, not paying attention to each other, one eating behind the counter, another rubbing her nose, a third cutting apart a cardboard box with a bread knife, I was served by another carrying my food in one hand and a large baking sheet full of cookies in the other. Also very pricey, I don't think I'm coming back despite the food.

LzrntchmgPHmvTuhdZV6fg.text: Hands down, my favorite lunch option downtown. Fantastic sandwiches/salads/side dishes, and their catering is PHENOMENAL.   For people who complain about the price: have you been to au bon pain lately? It's a comparable price, and I'm willing to pay $1 or so more to support a local business (with way better food).

9hk8nrgnPFIdRAskPsIDeQ.text: Just a chance to put in my $.02 on the Bluebird, since it has been Yelped about so many times.    Fantastic lunch spot Downtown. I hear it is a great breakfast, too.  Looked at the menu on the chalkboard above the counter and notice that the specials and soups were only on the little sign out front.  So I asked and found that one of my fave's hot butternut squash soup was available.  It was so cold and the hot soup was delicious.  The Cuban sandwich went perfectly with the soup. The cookies and salads looked great, next time.  What a great alternative Downtown.

duBl2AdWP8gfx9pg6Uuvaw.text: Came here based on Yelp rating but was sorely disappointed.   Ordered Turkey sandwich and received it promptly. In fact it had been pre made, but seemed fresh.  It had a couple of thin toppings of their specialty condiments (avocado and something else) but it was very dry.  I asked for some mustard and was offered a mustard dressing for 80 cents.  I asked if they just had some plain mustard and, after checking with the kitchen, was told no.   A sandwich shop without mustard?  The sandwich would have been perfect for $5 or even $8 on the high end, but I paid nearly $10 for a basic sandwich and a glass of ice water with no table service.   Wanting to give them one more chance and still hungry, I decided to try their Peanut Butter cookie sandwich (2 cookies filled with a cream frosting).  Once again, the taste was okay (although slightly burned and overlooked), but the cost was nearly $3.   I probably won't be going back soon.

KHudgeiCAPNs0yeRcTlSmQ.text: Loved this little gem!  It's not really an "eat in" as most of the people at the counter are waiting for their take out order. Best to take your food and eat at a table in Market Square. Breakfast only served until 10:30. Get there early as they do run out of menu items. The steel cut oatmeal cooked in coconut water was soooo tasty.  My husband raves about the breakfast sandwich.   I really wanted to the the sweet potato hash but they were all out of.  Closed on the weekends and only open until 3pm.

rjozStMkvMWlmeIn-kpkKw.text: This is my favorite lunch spot.  The sandwiches are awesome and worth the price.  The sides are always a fresh, healthy option.  I usually get two small sides, which is more than enough to fill you up, and it's about $5.   The owner, Liz, is always so pleasant and happy to see regulars.  The entire staff is so friendly and helpful.  If you're not sure about any of the menu options they are always ready to explain and even offer suggestions. The soups are absolutely delicious.  The coffee and beverage selection is unique and equally as tasty as the food options.   The pastries are on another level.  I always have such a hard time walking past them on the way to the register without picking up one.   DEFINITELY try Bluebird and I'm positive you'll become a regular, too! I wish there was a 6 star option, because they totally deserve it.  I'm so grateful there's a lunch option like this in Market Square!

photos.caption: Photo of Bluebird Kitchen - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Breakfast pastry with maple icing and BACON!!!

ZC9Cy53ZkkDU01SfFdylpw.text: I follow a Vegan diet and the Bluebird has plenty of options. The service is always top notch as well- they are always friendly no matter how many annoying questions I ask... Much appreciated as I am aware of how much of a pain special dietary needs can be.  Best Soy Lattes in town, hands down- they come with two shots of espresso: perfect. Vegan chocolate chip cookies are to die for- prefer them over normal cookies.  Highly recommended. Sure, a bit pricey, but I you want homemade you have to pay for it. Absolutely worth every penny!

zQMji5X3RE9oZgcz2AOqgw.text: Their ice coffee is superlative.   The perfect spot to grab a bite while exploring Pittsburgh, we started our day with the egg sandwich and a smoothie.  Well made and great bread.  While I question the wisdom of lettuce on a warm sandwich in general.. The food is top notch.

sLGFAG3EMPyJcO3rP8k1lg.text: Great atmosphere, excellent food, friendly staff. Downtown lunch favorite. I always get the roast beef sammich

51YZaALUiC5pKKnbZd5rrw.text: Amazing!  We stopped for breakfast this morning and I was very impressed.  The decor is very classy; it almost feels you stepped into a NY deli or something.  Wood counters, huge thick cutting boards displaying baked goods, jazz playing, and artfully written chalkboard menus on the wall.  The coffee is good, and the breakfast sandwiches are better.  I had local fried egg + cheddar on a pretzel roll, which to my delight was HUGE and came with fresh lettuce and tomato.  For $4?!?!  Take that, Egg McMuffin.  The husband had pastrami cured salmon and cucumber on an everything bagel.  He said it was awesome.  We will definitely make more breakfast stops here, but I'm also looking forward to trying lunch.  Everything on the menu looked so delicious, plus they had pumpkin pecan bread pudding...couldn't bring myself to order it for breakfast, but I'm going to have to try it someday soon!

GbHOfTXh2IduUk-bDFDf9w.text: This place is so new that when my friend suggested we go there for lunch, I had never even heard of it.  Fortunately, always up for something new, I agreed to go and I think I found a new favorite lunch spot downtown!  Bluebird Kitchen is located just around the corner of market square, next to Chipotle, and really sticks out as an original, non-chain, clean and cute bakery/eatery.  The inside is a gorgeous open space and very clean.  Their lunch menu is made up of an extensive selection of sandwiches, soups, salads and various sides.  (I didn't see the breakfast menu, but was informed they will start serving it tomorrow.)  In addition to lunch and breakfast, they had an array of delicious looking desserts.  The best part about Bluebird Kitchen is that everything is homemade daily, which is so refreshing.    For my lunch I got the Cuban sandwich and a cup of gazpacho.  My sandwich, served warm, was to die for!!  I could eat this sandwich for every meal and be a happy girl, except now I'm too intrigued and want to try everything else.  I did try to order the chicken salad sandwich at first, but they were all out of chicken salad.  (I went for a late lunch and they said this was a best seller - obviously I will be back to try it asap.)  My gazpacho was refreshing - I prefer a little more spice in mine, but I'm sure it's a bit different every day since it's made fresh.    As my friend and I were waiting for out food to be made, the owner, Liz (I think,) came to chat with us and was super friendly and genuinely interested in what we ordered.  She even offered me a free dessert while we waited!  (She clearly knew the way to my heart.)  I thought she just meant a free sample, but she gave me a whole gigantic cookie sandwich!  I'd be lying if I said this didn't make my day, maybe even week. :)  I got the chocolate cookie sandwich with pistachio filling.  Honestly, every dessert looked marvelous but I have a soft spot for pistachio desserts.  Like everything else, this cookie sandwich was excellent and I wish I could eat a dozen of them at once.  My only suggestion would be that they put some chairs or seating in the space.  There are bar tops along two walls that some people were eating at standing up, but the space is definitely big enough to put in some small tables/chairs or at least stools at the bar tops.  My friend and I had planned to eat outside so this didn't affect us - it would just be a nice option.    I will be recommending this place to everyone I know - I even grabbed some menus to put in my office.  I really hope the best for this place and think we need more unique eateries like this downtown.  I can't wait to go back and slowly, but surely, try the rest of the menu!

GoWZYWli57fpdb2cRU6W5w.text: I work downtown at a local Hotel, and was dragged here one day by a fellow staff member.  I'd just like to say, that if I had the money; i'd be going here every week! Whenever I have cash in my wallet, and am craving a delicious homemade sandwich, I go here on my lunch break!  My favorite would most certainly by the amazing Chicken Salad Sandwich. Filled with chicken, mayo, granny smith green apples, cumin, and cashews on a huge croisant roll, it will fill your stomach to the point of bursting.  More often than not, I have to wrap up the other half and take it home!  The delicious bakery portion of the small cafe always smells delicious (however, I'm a picky eater, and haven't found something I'd like to try).  The only complaint is that the wait times are a bit too long (especially if you want lunch; but come 10 minutes before 11am, which is when they start serving it). However, the above was solved by asking if their was a solution; they told me to call to place a to go order about 5-10 minutes before leaving work and it'll be ready by the time I get there)! How great is that customer service?!  All in all- I hope they NEVER take the Chicken Salad Sandwich off the menu. If so, I'm sure I'll find something just as delicious when I go back week after week!

eq8QCsj5lKMlskRqb5pSJw.text: I went here twice in two days. The first for lunch, where I had the salad with tuna, hard boiled egg, oven dried tomatoes, and haricot verts and a GF peanut butter bacon cookie. The cookie was so amazing! I was dubious at first of the flavour but was really surprised at how much I liked it! If you're looking for a quick salad, this is a good option because they are pre-made with your choice of dressing on the side. The next day I came back for breakfast with a friend. Although the experience was fine, I was a little bit irked with the service. First, we wanted to share the "frittata" and a smoothie. It is unclear on the menu that it's actually a frittata sandwich served on a roll. Being gluten free, my friend asked for a substitute for the bread -- anything without wheat. The girl helping us said we could get the granola/yoghurt INSTEAD of the bread, but when we went to check out she charged us for the whole parfait. If I hear "instead of" without a follow up of a price change, I assume it's for free and don't want to be charged for it. We ended up having just the frittata without bread which was fine. The other problem was that I asked for almond milk for my coffee and the girl said they didn't have any almond milk but could give me soy milk. But we had ordered the "April smoothie" which had almond milk in it and when I asked about that she said, "oh right, I was going to make it with soy milk." We ended up not having a problem with the soy milk, but I think it's dangerous to not mention it because it is possible we had a soy allergy and specifically ordered the smoothie because of the almond milk! We didn't mind the soy milk in the smoothie at all, but I think it is something they should have mentioned to us before making it. I wanted to get another peanut butter bacon cookie, but they said they don't sell them at breakfast which is a huge bummer! I hope I can come back and have it again another time soon.

StvIc5R4j4w4cP07TQolBw.text: I've wanted to try their food for awhile ever since I saw someone mention this place in the Pittsburgh Gazette. I finally had the chance one Friday afternoon after I getting espresso grounds from Nicholas's Coffee Company. I unfortunately had already ate but was slightly hungry so I ordered one of their side dishes (which change daily). Their quinoa salad was the perfect protein packed snack consisting of arugula, gouda, and apples. I enjoyed the refreshness of this side dish and would definitely come back on an empty stomach to try their entrees!

uPaVq13OLDFZXWNkFSgH2A.text: Would've given this place 4 stars but it just didn't feel right especially when I have this place two chances to redeem themselves. It wasn't the food that was bad- more so the staff. I ordered the local egg sandwich with bacon on ciabatta. Tasted great and nothing short of how I pictured it. I also ordered their smoothie of the day (kale, blueberries, etc.). That's where it went all wrong. I saw the staff use their bare hands to put the fruits and vegetables in while wiping his hands on his pants with the occasion combing of his hair. I wish I didn't see all that. I couldn't sit back and drink that...I had to ask for him to keep the drink. I swapped it with their freshly squeezed orange juice. This time he put on his gloves...the juice was delightful but the outside of the cup was all sticky (he probably didn't care at that point). And this all happened during the first visit. The second visit, I ordered the local egg sandwich with bacon on a pretzel roll. However, I got the sandwich on a ciabatta roll. Sandwich was good but wasn't what I ordered. Wish the staff was more attentive...

IbHRyVGmW2It7zR_SjoivQ.text: I've been to Bluebird several times over the past few years since I work so close to Market Square. Sadly after my experience today I won't be back. This morning I stopped in for oatmeal and a coffee and had to ask one of the employees to take my order. Apparently she was taking a phone order but never told me that. I told her what I wanted and waited patiently while she continued to talk on the phone.   More people came in and other workers took their orders. After about 5-10 minutes I became frustrated and told another employee how long I had been waiting and then left.   This is not the first time I've experienced bad customer service at Bluebird. Most of the workers are rude and unfriendly.

Q6Wn3t_RxZTmcumH8-ap2g.text: This is my favorite place to eat downtown. If I am around the area at lunch time I'm sure to stop in...heck, if I'm in the area I stop in no matter what time and take a home a pastry. I love the macarons, the chicken salad sandwich, the hot chocolate, and SO much more. I heard the owner speak at an event and really like her story. It really makes me appreciate supporting businesses that support Pittsburgh. I love following along on Instagram, too. Great photos and a good reminder to stop in!

Q2yHK7Z170gII7EmHbdXyg.text: The Stanwix St. location is the best part of my morning ritual: (1) tackle the overnight email traffic, (2) grab a cuppa joe, (3) get a takeout Savory Oat Bowl from the Bluebird.  I've never been any kind of oatmeal fan, but this amazing combo of chicken stock, oats, braised kale and fried egg has me singing its praises with a convert's zeal. I often need to work through lunch on various events, and the savory oat bowl *easily* keeps me going until suppertime, with maybe an apple or two along the way.  It's a perfect breakfast, and a great value.

wUHaqzFe5L2cDXIZHs5JXA.text: I used to love this place a few years ago. Everything was fresh and unique and the baked goods were delicious.  Today I stopped in for the Baby Romaine salad that they've had on the menu since they opened (another favorite of mine). Unfortunately, their salads seem to be similar in quality and flavor these days to the ones you find in the cooler at a Rite Aid or CVS. Whatever they did to the marcona almonds made them seem chewy and stale, the romaine was wilted and browning, and there were barely any dates.  With tax, it wasn't a great way to spend 8 bucks on lunch. Here's hoping they get back to the fresh old days.

OGN7550CTsxTvro8gpeMbQ.text: I used Bluebird last week for a breakfast in-service for work. I ordered some mini (as in one bite each) quiches, fruit, assorted pastries and coffee for 20 people. The total was over $400!!! that's over $20/person, for fruit and quiche! I could understand that price if I was serving some gourmet breakfast spread; but this was not gourmet. The quiches were pretty good and the fruit was fresh, though the pastries were pretty bland and unappealing...most of them went untouched.  I am not sure what is more outrageous when I look at the bill; the $37.50 for paper plates and utensils or the $55 for two boxes of coffee. That is literally twice the price of a box of joe from Dunkin. Absurd. I'm glad they didn't deliver, who know how much that charge would have been!

PEXx514Of56Rv0qfw2oaLQ.text: My favorite spot for lunch in downtown Pittsburgh. The food is delicious and inspired - not the generic sandwiches and sodas you get at a corner deli. I've had their soups, sandwiches, sides, desserts, and coffee. The breakfast menu looks amazing as well but I'm never downtown for breakfast so I can't say much about that.  The prices are a bit higher for a meal than, say, nearby Chipotle or Subway, but the quality of the food you get more than makes up for the difference in my opinion. I usually get a small soup and small side and that's enough for a satisfying lunch for me and comes out to be about $7-8. They have a core menu of items and also daily and monthly specials so there's always something new to try. One thing to keep in mind is that the sandwiches are made to order while the salads are pre-made that morning and in to-go boxes.   Seating is limited to bar-style seating along the wall and windows, which works fine for me since I'm usually just looking to grab a quick lunch during the workday and not to have a long sit-down meal.  I hope Bluebird Kitchen never leaves downtown because there's really no other similar spot downtown like it.
